Georges M√©li√®s is one of my favorite film makers. The way he melded his magician background with new technologies to come up with special effects at the turn of the 1900s was nothing less that incredible.  This museum was great. Got to see a lot of original gear used by Georges as well as the history and background.  Larger placards are translated into English, but you will want to use Google Translate.  I spent about 2 hours here with the gift shop
Visited for Art of James Cameron, which was excellent. The permanent collection is also a must see. Well worth a.cisit and gift shop is also one of the best I've been to.

A real discovery tour of the very initial stages of motion pictures. Meli√©s was the original master of special effects, and the museum shows how he brought his knowledge of magic, theater, production, and the new motion cameras all together to create movies with fantastic scenes that people could not believe.  For years, he was the chief inventor of special effect techniques such as stop motion and mattes. Then, he was the inventor of the concept of the motion picture studio, erecting a dedicated building. His studio was  like a greenhouse and a classic theater all in one, optimized to capture the sun's light to make the production of films easier before electric lights were a practical tool.  This exhibit was inside the Cin√©math√®que, which also featured a temporary exhibit about James Cameron's creative genius. This too was exceedingly interesting.

The Mus√©e M√©li√®s in Paris is an unmissable stop for film and non-cinema enthusiasts. Located at the Cin√©math√®que Fran√ßaise, this museum offers a fascinating journey through the history of cinema, starting from the first discoveries and passing through Lumi√©re with a particular focus on the pioneering work of Georges M√©li√®s. The museum explores the early stages of cinema, showing how the art form has evolved from its silent beginnings to the present day. Much of the museum is dedicated to M√©li√®s, the movie magician, with displays including costumes, models, props and never-before-seen archives.  Visitors can try their hand at running a cinema and more!, offering a hands-on and immersive experience that pays homage to M√©li√®s' cinematic techniques. In addition to celebrating the past, the museum also includes a section dedicated to modern cinema, showing the evolution of cinematic techniques and narratives up to the present day. The Mus√©e M√©li√®s is not just a place of exhibition, but an immersive experience that captures the imagination of adults and children, paying homage to one of cinema's greatest innovators.
Beautiful exhibition, you can even use some accessories to do your own experiments, it's a very nice outing

A place full of magic and poetry where the life and work of Georges M√©li√®s is remembered. Objects are on display and unfortunately not all of these films can be seen since many have been destroyed. The cinema of Georges M√©li√®s is in the spotlight, but not only that. I won't say any more ü§´ I prefer to let you discover the museum not at a running pace but quietly and while soaking up this place which I am sure will enchant you, whatever your age. Before going out, stop by the shop to take a souvenir with you and if you still have a little time left, for only 2 euros on top of your entry ticket, go see a black and white film in the cinema.
